citations.narrative:
Representatives reported that on or around July 7th, 2025, strong gusts of wind during a severe storm blew a wooden
door that normally opens outward, into an enclosure causing damage to the door frame and leaving a small gap. The gap
in the door allowed 3 northern bobwhite quail to get out of their outdoor primary enclosure. The facility representatives
stated that they heard the birds calling nearby for multiple days after they got out but haven’t seen or heard them since.
Primary enclosures must be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to securely contain the animals. Lack of
secure containment can increase stress, discomfort, cause health issues and doesn't ensure their well-being. Correct by
ensuring that all housing facilities are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to contain the animals securely.
***Correct from August 27, 2025 going forward.

A wooden shelter box in the cockatoo enclosure has not been maintained free from sharp points or edges. It has been
worn/chewed on top and metal nail-heads are sticking out. Metal nailheads could cause injury. Ensure that furniture-type
objects provided are maintained to prevent harm to the birds housed.
***Correct by August 29, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
SCOTT WELCH, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.153(a)(1)(iii)  Critical
   
Primary enclosures. 
Representatives reported that on or around July 7th, 2025, strong gusts of wind during a severe storm blew a wooden 
door that normally opens outward, into an enclosure causing damage to the door frame and leaving a small gap. The gap 
in the door allowed 3 northern bobwhite quail to get out of their outdoor primary enclosure. The facility representatives 
stated that they heard the birds calling nearby for multiple days after they got out but haven’t seen or heard them since. 
Primary enclosures must be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to securely contain the animals. Lack of 
secure containment can increase stress, discomfort, cause health issues and doesn't ensure their well-being. Correct by 
ensuring that all housing facilities are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to contain the animals securely.  
***Correct from August 27, 2025 going forward. 
3.153(a)(2) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
A wooden shelter box in the cockatoo enclosure has not been maintained free from sharp points or edges. It has been 
worn/chewed on top and metal nail-heads are sticking out. Metal nailheads could cause injury. Ensure that furniture-type 
objects provided are maintained to prevent harm to the birds housed.  
***Correct by August 29, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
SCOTT WELCH, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
